sub_topic: Applying the Fourier transform to signal processing
message_1: Given a continuous-time signal $x(t) = 2\sin(3\pi t) + 3\cos(5\pi t)$, find its Fourier transform $X(\omega)$ and plot its magnitude and phase spectrum. Also, find the frequency components present in the signal $x(t)$.
message_2:
To find the Fourier transform $X(\omega)$ of the given signal $x(t) = 2\sin(3\pi t) + 3\cos(5\pi t)$, we can use the linearity property of the Fourier transform and the fact that the Fourier transform of a sine and cosine function are given by:

$$\mathcal{F}\{\sin(at)\} = \frac{1}{2j}[\delta(\omega - a) - \delta(\omega + a)]$$
$$\mathcal{F}\{\cos(at)\} = \frac{1}{2}[\delta(\omega - a) + \delta(\omega + a)]$$

where $\delta(\omega)$ is the Dirac delta function, and $j$ is the imaginary unit.

Applying the Fourier transform to $x(t)$, we get:

$$X(\omega) = 2\mathcal{F}\{\sin(3\pi t)\} + 3\mathcal{F}\{\cos(5\pi t)\}$$

Substituting the Fourier transform expressions for sine and cosine, we get:

$$X(\omega) = 2\left(\frac{1}{2j}[\delta(\omega - 3\pi) - \delta(\omega + 3\pi)]\right) + 3\left(\frac{1}{2}[\delta(\omega - 5\pi) + \delta(\omega + 5\pi)]\right)$$

Simplifying the expression, we get:

$$X(\omega) = \frac{1}{j}[\delta(\omega - 3\pi) - \delta(\omega + 3\pi)] + \frac{3}{2}[\delta(\omega - 5\pi) + \delta(\omega + 5\pi)]$$

Now, let's find the magnitude and phase spectrum of $X(\omega)$.

The magnitude spectrum is given by:

$$|X(\omega)| = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}
1 & \text{for } \omega = \pm 3\pi \\
\frac{3}{2} & \text{for } \omega = \pm 5\pi \\
0 & \text{otherwise}
\end{array} \right.$$

The phase spectrum is given by:

$$\angle X(\omega) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}
-\frac{\pi}{2} & \text{for } \omega = 3\pi \\
\frac{\pi}{2} & \text{for } \omega = -3\pi \\
0 & \text{for } \omega = \pm 5\pi \\
\text{undefined} & \text{otherwise}
\end{array} \right.$$

The frequency components present in the signal $x(t)$ can be found by looking at the non-zero values of the magnitude spectrum. In this case, the frequency components are:

$$\omega_1 = \pm 3\pi \Rightarrow f_1 = \pm \frac{3}{2} \text{ Hz}$$
$$\omega_2 = \pm 5\pi \Rightarrow f_2 = \pm \frac{5}{2} \text{ Hz}$$
